title-group.article-title: Load frequency control using multi-stage fuzzy logic controller for wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system

article-meta.aff: 1Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
2Government College of Engineering, Bargur, Tamilnadu, India

author-notes.corresp: Dhanalakshmi Rangaswami, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India Email: dhanalaxmisk@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents an analysis of multi-stage fuzzy logic control (FLC) application for load frequency control (LFC) of an isolated wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system. Due to the sudden load changes and intermittent wind power, large frequency fluctuation problems can occur. The LFC deviates the frequency deviation and maintains dynamic performance of the system. In this paper, a multi-stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative (PID) controller is proposed for LFC of an isolated wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system. Simulations are performed for this hybrid system with the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller, conventional PI controller and FLC with different load disturbances and wind input disturbances. The performance of the proposed approach is verified from simulations and comparisons. Simulation results explicitly show that the performance of the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller is superior to the conventional PI controller and FLC in terms of overshoot, settling time and steady state error against various load changes and variations of wind inputs.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In most remote and isolated areas, electric power is often supplied to the local community by diesel generators. Due to the environmental and economic impacts of a diesel generator, interest in alternative cost-efficient and pollution-free energy generation has grown enormously (Hunter and Elliot, 1994). Currently, wind is the fastest growing and most widely utilized renewable energy technology in power systems. Moreover, wind power is expected to be economically attractive when the wind speed of the proposed site is considerable, for electrical generation and electric energy is not easily available from the grid (Ackerman, 2005). Wind power is intermittent due to worst case weather conditions, so wind power generation is variable an unpredictable. Wind power is not fully controllable and its availability depends on daily and seasonal patterns (Lipman, 1989). As a result, conventional energy sources such as diesel generators are used in conjunction with renewable energy for reliable operation. The hybrid wind power with diesel generation has been suggested by Lipman (1989) and Hunter and Elliot (1994) to handle the above problem.

The unsteady nature of wind and frequent change in load demands may cause large and severe oscillation of power. The fluctuation of output power of such renewable sources may cause a serious problem of frequency and voltage fluctuation of the grid (Hunter and Elliot, 1994; Ackerman, 2005). It is, therefore, necessary to have a proper control strategy for maintaining the scheduled frequency. An effective controller for stabilizing frequency oscillations and maintaining the system frequency within acceptable range is significantly required. Research studies were conducted from the past for load frequency control (LFC) of a thermal power system with conventional and intelligent controllers (Chang and Fu, 1997; Cam and Kocaarslan, 2005; Juang and Lu, 2006; Cam, 2007; Shayeghi et al., 2007; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2003, 2009; Sheikh et al., 2009). LFC was designed for the wind-diesel hybrid system with a conventional controller by Bhatti et al. (1997a). LFC using fuzzy logic controller (FLC) was designed with a different approach and with optimization techniques for an isolated wind diesel hybrid system (Chokpansuwan et al., 2008; Chaiyatham et al., 2009). To meet the increasing load demand for an isolated community, expansion of the wind diesel hybrid power system is required. A micro hydro generating unit is added in parallel where water streams are abundantly available. The resulting wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system must provide good quality service to the consumer load, which depends mostly on the type and action of the generation controller (Bhatti et al., 1997b). In the proposed paper, multi-stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative (PID) controller has been applied to design LFC for a wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system. Chokpansuwan et al. (2008) and Chaiyatham et al. (2009) designed the LFC with fuzzy logic PID only for minimising the frequency deviation of an isolated wind-diesel hybrid system for 0.01 p.u. step load disturbance. The proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller in this work, not only damps out the frequency oscillation but also maintains the wind power generation and hydro power generation for an isolated wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system for various step load disturbances and wind input disturbances. The hybrid wind-micro hydro-diesel system is very reliable because the diesel acts as a cushion to take care of variation in wind speed and would always maintain an average power equal to the set point (Hunter and Elliot, 1994).

The proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller for a governor in diesel side and a blade pitch control in wind side are designed individually for the wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system. The proposed multi-stage FLC is used to tune the Kp and Ki of PI controller in the first stage and the parameter Kd is tuned in the second stage to improve the performance further. In this paper, a conventional PI controller and FLC are designed and simulated individually for comparison with the proposed multi-stage FLC for wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system. Simulation results show the superior performance of the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller in comparison with the conventional PI controller and FLC in terms of the settling time, overshoot against various load changes and variations of wind inputs.

sec.title: 2. System configuration
sec.p:
The configuration of isolated wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system is shown in Figure 1. In the hybrid system considered, synchronous generator is connected on a diesel-generator (DG) and induction generators connected on wind turbine and on hydro turbine (Bansal et al., 2003). The blade pitch controller is installed in the wind side while the governor is equipped with the diesel side. Due to the imbalance between the real power generation and the load demand (plus losses), the kinetic energy of rotation to be either added to or taken from the generating units (generator shaft either speeded up or slowed down) and the frequency of system varies as a result .Whenever the real power demand changes, a frequency change occurs. This frequency error is amplified, mixed and changed to a command signal which is sent to the turbine governor (Elgerd and Fosha, 1970; Hadi, 1999; Kundur, 2008). The governor operates to restore the balance between the input and output by changing the turbine output. Figure 1.
Configuration of isolated wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system.

The supplementary controller of the diesel generating unit, called the LFC may satisfy the requirements. The function of the controller is to generate raise or lower command signals to the diesel engine (Bhatti et al., 1997a). To stabilize the frequency oscillation Bhatti et al. (1997b) have used a conventional PI control method to design LFC for wind-diesel-micro hydro hybrid system. The transfer function block diagram of a hybrid wind-micro hydro-diesel power generation used in this study is shown in Figure 2. In the wind-turbine generating unit, the multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller is designed as a supplementary controller for the pitch control. This controller detects the deviation of the wind power generation (ΔPgw) as an input signal, so that the wind power generation can be maintained constant. For the diesel generating unit also, the multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller is designed to improve the performance of the governor. It uses a system frequency deviation (Δfs) of the power system as a feedback input, so that it can offset the mismatch between generation and load demand by adjusting the speed changer position. Figure 2.
Simulink model of load frequency control using multi stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative controller for wind-micro hydro-diesel hybrid system.

The continuous time dynamic behavior of the LFC system is modeled by a set of state vector differential equations. (1)X'=AX+BU+Γp where X, U and p are the state, control and disturbance vectors, respectively. A, B and Γ are real constant matrices, of appropriate dimensions, associated with the above vectors.

sec.title: 3. Conventional proportional integral controller
sec.p: Among the various types of LFC, the PI controller is most widely applied to speed-governor systems for LFC schemes. One advantage of the PI controller is that it reduces the steady-state error to zero. The performance specifications of the systems such as rise time, overshoot, settling time and steady state error can be minimized by tuning the value of parameters Kp and Ki of the PI controller, because each component has its own special purposes.
Mathematically it is represented as (2)U(s)=Kp*E(s)+Ki*∫E(s)

Since the conventional PI controller with fixed gains has been designed at nominal operating conditions, it fails to provide the best control performance over a wide range of operating conditions and exhibits poor dynamic performance. To solve this problem, fuzzy logic techniques have been proposed (Cam and Kocaarslan, 2005; Juang and Lu, 2006; Cam, 2007; Shayeghi et al., 2007; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2003, 2009; Sheikh et al., 2009). System operating conditions are monitored and used as inputs to a fuzzy system whose output signal controls the inputs to governor for increasing or decreasing the generation for maintaining the system frequency.

sec.title: 4. Fuzzy logic controller
sec.p: FLCs are knowledge-based controllers usually derived from a knowledge acquisition process or automatically synthesized from self-organizing control architectures. The fuzzy logic based control has extensively received attention in various power systems applications (Cirstea et al., 2002; Ross, 2004). It can be easily implemented in power systems for LFC (Cam and Kocaarslan, 2005; Juang and Lu, 2006; Cam 2007; Anand and Jeyakumar, 2009; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2009). The LFC problem considered here is composed of the sudden small load perturbations or a change in wind input power which continuously disturb the normal operation of a power system. Hence, the deviations of frequency must be controlled by this FLC technique.

caption.p: Block diagram of conventional proportional integral controller.

sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the FLC designed for comparison with the proposed controller. The input variable (Δfs) in the diesel side for governor and the input variable (ΔPgw) in the wind side for blade pitch control are used as error signals for FLC. Here, the FLC consists of seven membership functions (two trapezoidal memberships and five triangular memberships) for two-input and one-output variable as shown in Figure 5. The control rules are shown in Table 1. where every cell shows the output membership function of a control rule with two input membership functions. For example, consider the fifth row and second column, which means: if e (Δfs) is PS and Δe (Δfs’) is NM, then control output u is NS. The linguistic variables are negative large, negative medium, negative small, zero, positive small, positive medium, positive large (NL, NM, NS, Z, PS, PM, PL). Figure 4.
Fuzzy logic controller on diesel side and wind side.
Figure 5.
Input and output membership functions for fuzzy logic controller.
Table 1.
Rule base (with seven membership functions)
e/Δe NL NM NS Z PS PM PL
NL NL NL NL NL NM NS Z
NM NL NM NM NM NS Z PS
NS NL NM NS NS Z PS PM
Z NL NM NS Z PS PM PL
PS NM NS Z PS PS PM PL
PM NS Z PS PM PM PM PL
PL Z PS PM PL PL PL PL

sec.title: 5. Multi-stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative controller
sec.p:
The structure of the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller is shown in Figure 6. It consists of a pre-compensator with two FLCs, which tune the parameters Kp and Ki of PI control block. And still to improve the performance of the hybrid system, another FLC is included to tune the parameter Kd of derivative control block in the next stage. Each FLC in the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller has two input variables and one output variable with seven triangular membership functions. Similar to FLC which is designed for comparison, the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller also uses the input variable (Δfs) in the diesel side for governor and the input variable (ΔPgw) in the wind side for blade pitch control as an error signal. The membership functions and rule base of the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller is shown in Figure 7 and Tables 2, 3 and 4 respectively. The Rule base of the proposed controller is formed with the linguistic variables NL, NM, NS, Z, PS, PM, PL for input variables and the linguistic variables zero, very small, medium small, medium, medium big, very big and very large (Z, VS, MS, M, MB, VB, VL) for output variable Kp, Ki, Kd. The membership functions, parameters and control rules are used to design the PID parameters (Kp, Ki and Kd) to control the system. (3)e*Kp+Ki*∫e=FPIKd*(de/dt)=FDFPI+FD=U Figure 6.
Schematic block diagram of multi stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative controller.
Figure 7.
Input and output membership functions for multi stage fuzzy logic proportional integral derivative controller.

tr.td: System parameters for this power rating

sec.p: Here ‘e’(Δfs for diesel side and ΔPgw for the wind side) is the error between desired position set point and the output, Δe(Δfs’) is the change in error on the diesel side of multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller. The PID parameters (Kp, Ki and Kd) are tuned by fuzzy inference, which provide a nonlinear mapping from the error (Δfs) and change in error (Δfs’) to PID parameters Kp, Ki and Kd. (4)μPi=min(μ(e),μ(Δe))μIi=min(μ(e),μ(Δe))μDi=min(μ(e),μ(Δe))
Every cell of the rule base table shows the output membership function of a control rule with two input membership functions. For example, consider the sixth row and fifth column which means:
For the PID parameter Kp- if e is PM and Δe is PS, then Kp is VS, for the parameter Ki- if e is PM and Δe is PS, then Ki is VB and for the parameter Kd - if e is PM and Δe is PS, then Kd is MB.

sec.title: 6. Simulation and results
sec.p: Simulations were performed using the parameters given in Table 5, with FLC, conventional PI controller and the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller for the Simulink model of wind –micro hydro-diesel hybrid power system.

Simulations are carried out for the step load changes of 1%, 2%, 3%, 4% and 10% (ΔPL = 0.01, 0.02, 0.03. 0.04, 0.1p.u.) to the hybrid system at t = 0 s. The change in frequency of the system, change in wind power generation, change in diesel power generation and change in hydro power generation for 0.01 p.u. step load change is shown in Figures 8(a), (b), (c) and (d) respectively for the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller conventional PI controller and FLC .The settling time to attain steady state, value are observed and tabulated in Table 6 for the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller, FLC and conventional PI controller for change in frequency response, change in wind power generation, change in diesel power generation and hydro power generation for various step load changes. The performance criteria considered for the comparison are settling time, overshoot and steady state error values. In the second case, the responses of change in frequency and change in wind power generation are simulated against change in wind input power (step change 0.01 p.u.) for the proposed multi-stage Fuzzy logic PID controller and conventional PI controller which is shown in Figures 9(a) and (b). The change in frequency of the system, change in wind power generation, change in diesel power generation and change in hydro power generation for 0.02 p.u. step load change is shown in Figures 10(a), (b), (c) and (d) respectively for the proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller, conventional PI controller and FLC. Matlab 7.3-Simulink software and fuzzy logic tool box are used for simulation on a PC Intel core 2Duo Processor, 2.2 GHz, 4 GB RAM under Windows XP. The overshoot and setting time of proposed multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller are lower than those of conventional PI controller and FLC. Figure 8.
(a) Frequency deviation of the hybrid system for the step load change of 1% (0.01pu). (b) Change in wind power generation for the step load change of 1% (0.01pu). (c) Change in diesel power generation for the step load change of 1% (0.01pu). (d) Change in hydro power generation for the step load change of 1 % (0.01pu).
Figure 9.
(a) Frequency deviation of the hybrid system for the step wind input disturbance of 1% (0.01pu). (b) Change in wind power generation for the step wind input disturbance of 1% (0.01pu).
Figure 10.
(a) Frequency deviation of the hybrid system for the step load change of 2% (0.02pu). (b) Change in wind power generation for the step load change of 2% (0.02pu). (c) Change in diesel power generation for the step load change of 2% (0.02pu). (d) Change in hydro power generation for the step load change of 2% (0.02pu).

FLC: fuzzy logic controller; FLPIDC: Fuzzy logic Proportional Integral Derivative controller; PIC: Proportional Integral controller.

It can be observed that the proposed multi-stage FLC and other controllers which are designed and compared for LFC, maintain the system frequency and wind power generation in constant steady state value by controlling the generation of the diesel power generating unit. Simulation results explicitly show that the performance of the proposed multi-stage FLC is superior to the conventional controllers in terms of overshoot, settling time against various load changes and wind input power changes. Damping out of frequency oscillation is better with the proposed multistage fuzzy logic PID controller than the conventional PI controller designed by Bhatti et al. (1997b) for wind-diesel-micro hydro hybrid system. Chokpansuwan et al. (2008) and Chaiyatham et al. (2009) designed the LFC with fuzzy logic PID, which concentrated only on minimizing the frequency deviation of an isolated wind-diesel hybrid system for 0.01 p.u. step load disturbance. But, the proposed multistage fuzzy logic PID controller minimizes all the factors such as frequency deviation, change in wind power generation, change in diesel power generation and change in hydro power generation and that too for wide range of step load disturbances(0.01 p.u. to 0.1 p.u.). The proposed controller also deviates the frequency oscillation and change in wind power generation and brings to a steady state for 0.01 p.u. step wind input disturbance. It is possible to improve the performance of the system by further reducing the settling time, if the proposed controller concentrates only on the minimization of frequency deviation as in Chokpansuwan et al. (2008) and Chaiyatham et al. (2009). The multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller proposed in this paper not only minimizes the frequency deviation but also maintains the wind power generation and hydro power generation of the hybrid power system.

sec.title: 7. Conclusion
sec.p: The intelligent multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller for LFC of an isolated wind-micro hydro- diesel hybrid system provides a satisfactory performance compared to the conventional PI controller and FLC. Performance comparison of the proposed paper indicates that the system response of the LFC with multi-stage fuzzy logic PID controller has a quite short settling time and less overshoots than a conventional PI controller and FLC. It has been shown that the proposed controller is effective and provides significant improvement in system performance by automatically tuning the parameters Kp, Ki and Kd of a PID controller using multi-stage fuzzy logic technique. The proposed controller maintains the system reliably for sudden load changes and proves its superiority.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
